The status of different aspects of the airport, including approaches, runways, taxiways, gate and aircraft turn-around information

The ARESActivationService provides the CDM to coordinate the activation of an ARES between the ASM and the concerned ACCs.
The ARESActivationService contract allows:
The Airspace User updates the Status of the ARES locally and sends a message t

The ARESDeActivationService provides the CDM to coordinate the deactivation of an ARES between the ASM and the concerned ACCs.
Certain minutes before a planned activity ends, the ASM requests either a planned or an unplanned de-activation to the responsib
The ARES Pre-Activation service provides the CDM to coordinate the pre-activation of an ARES between the ASM and the concerned ACCs.
The ARESRelease service  notifies the release of a de-activated ARES to the concerned ACCs.

The Service aims to publish Aerodrome Map Features and the Maps themselves as described by EUROCAE in standard ED99C and ED119B. The Service design process of AMIS has been conducted in the Fast Track 6 initiative.
The service is provided by a AMDB data p

This service allows selecting the required aeronautical information by its feature type name and an advanced filter with spatial, temporal and logical operators.

Notice containing information concerning the establishment, condition or change in any aeronautical facility, service, procedure or hazard, the timely knowledge of which is essential to personnel concerned with flight operations. children.description: It concerns making access to the ATM system a fair and equitable process which is transparent to all Users.
It concerns the allocation of the airspace and surface structures in a manner which is flexible in implementation and operation and at the same time meeting the aspirations of all Users.

It concerns the long-term design of strategies, rules and procedures, by which the airspace and associated surface functions will be organized to accommodate the different types of air activity, volume of traffic, and differing levels and types of service

The service design has two purposes, to fulfil the top-down requirements and to be aligned with the real world prototype used by Validation Exercise 695, namely the BARCO AMAN System on the provider side at Heathrow TMA

Asset Management Service concerns the planning, management, monitoring and coordination of all the assets (infrastructure and resources) required for the provision of the ATM services. These assets will cover the need of airspace as well as the need and u

It has to activate when the separation mode has been compromised and separation provision has failed. It is generally provided by safety nets based on the ground or airborne system or by their cooperative action.

The Data link Taxi instructions service handles the transmission of various taxi clearances as well as taxi routes via data link.
In the new SESAR operating method planned for the future these clearances shall primarily be communicated by CPDLC through th

It ensures the most efficient balance between capacity and demand. It concerns looking for optimisation of available resources in readiness to introduce mitigation measures to maintain the ATM network stability.

The ExtendedFlightPlanSubmission service concerns the validation of an Extended Flight Plan (FPL) message before its submission,  the submission of Extended FPL/Extended Modification/Extended Delay message, the cancellation of an Extended Flight Plan and  search for Extended Flight Plans with a known  Identifier .
service covers the dissemination of standard ICAO AirportMETForecast bulletins over SWIM.

The Airport Met Nowcast Service provides a Meteorological prediction of the weather at the airport concerned, at a small interval in the future.
The publication consists of an Airport Meteorological Nowcast for the specified airport. The Service uses a Pu
service covers the dissemination of standard ICAO AirportMETObservation bulletins over SWIM.
Format for reporting weather information The METAR service covers the dissemination of standard ICAO METAR bulletins over SWIM.

A SNOWTAM is a message describing the conditions of the runways, taxiways and apron at an aerodrome. The SNOWTAM service covers the dissemination over SWIM of standard ICAO SNOWTAM, which are shared with a wide range of subscribing ATM users.

Performance Management Service concerns the management of the optimised performance of the ATM system. ATM system design will be determined by collaborative decision making based on system-wide information sharing and system-wide performance cases.

It concerns the collaborative design of a route structure that is implemented where required in the network and is flexible in its operation when implemented.  It concerns also the design of airport taxi routes.

Provision of surveillance services, providing positioning information from radar, satellite navigation systems, aircraft datalinks, etc.

It concerns the tactical establishment and maintenance of a safe, orderly and efficient flow of air traffic through, flight sequencing, spacing and, if necessary queuing, to optimize the use of scarce resources.
It concerns the execution of agreed trajectory and monitoring of the agreed trajectory to ensure that any deviations from the trajectory outside agreed parameters are detected.

It concerns the refinement of the Shared Business Trajectory/Shared Mission Trajectory in a collaborative and iterative process so that the latest published SBT/SMT reflects all known Network and Airport constraints. It ensures that the Users have the rig
The Service itself provides volcanic ash information to its stakeholders. Information can be filtered through various criteria (height, region, customizable filter).

children.description:
This functional block manages the system flight plans (SFPL) from the creation until their deletion
The Flight Data Processing applies to IFR and VFR flights and encompasses the following aspects
- Flight planning and lifecycle management creation and management of the system flight plan (SFPL) from the filed flight plan and associated planning messages, and management of internal SFPL states.
- Flight plan distribution distribution of flight data to sectors, other ATSUs, Air Defence organization, Airport Operations, CFMU.
- Coordination and transfer management of coordination and transfer between sectors and with external ATSUs; management of pre-departure clearance coordination; forwarding oceanic clearances.
- Civil/Military coordination notification and coordination of flights between civil and military ATS units.
- Processing of controller input  flight updates following ATC instructions and planning.
- Management of ADS-C uplink of contract requests to the aircraft and processing and dissemination of the downlinked data. 
- Trajectory prediction and management calculation of the trajectory and synchronization with the global trajectory shared between the concerned client and actors.
- Calculation and management  of what-if trajectories. 
- Flight Data Operator Interaction  management management of SFPL data handling and presentation to the Flight Data Operator

Multilateration, both wide area and local
Primary Surveillance Radar. Its performance is based on the transmission of a pulse of radio energy and the reception of the signal reflected by the objective

Enables the air-ground voice and data communication with aircrafts via satellites. It combines satellites, satellites ground stations with their equipment's.
The system is generally provided and operated by SITA/ARINC for ATC or FOC customers.

The Management and Control System allows system operators to control and manage SATCOM Interactive Network. Among its functions are the following it contains the modulation & demodulation blocks that allow the MCS to access the SATCOM Interactive Network; it possesses  the intelligence to grant/deny/control access to requests made by aircrafts & ground subscribers; it offers detailed information of network nodes; it performs management and control tasks directly on the nodes; it registers the accesses and operations to allow for audit of actions. And, for regenerative payloads, it controls the payload configuration through a specific secured communication link.
MCS works 24 x 7 x 365.

The Satellite Control Center allows satellite operators to remotely control the satellite once it’s been launched, and to keep it in its allocated spatial location. Via a telemetry link, SCC communicates with the satellite to ensure that all satellite subsystems are functioning as expected. 
SCC works 24 x 7 x 365.
Airport surveillance radar
Secondary Surveillance Radar. Its performance is based on the transmission of coded interrogations to aircraft transponders in various modes and the reception of coded responses.

children.description: Provides cellular connectivity such as 3G.
Technology for broadband wireless access systems designed to support mobility (cf Eurocae WG_82).

HF links Those within the band of 2100 – 28000 kHz
UHF links Those within the bands of 225 – 328.6 MHz and 335.4 – 400 MHz
Is a set of Media Access Control (MAC) and Physical Layer (PHY) specifications for implementing Wireless Local Area Networks (WLAN).
Satellite link is able to provide clear, worldwide and reliable communication channels.
Communications between aircrafts can occur over the UHF link provided by ADS-B, in the future 802.1x based broadband links with unmanned aerial systems.
VHF Data Link Mode 2 is a means of sending information between aircraft and ground stations. It has been implemented operationally to support Controller Pilot Data Link Communications (CPDLC)

The A/G Datalink radio infrastructure enables the air-ground data communication with aircrafts via radio. The infrastructure combines radio equipment's, antennas, based-station controllers (BSC), cabling. 
It uses the VHF ACARS communication (VDL Mode A), or/and VHF ATN (VDL Mode 2) above FL280 (Link2K+) and/or HF.

Enables voice communication between FOC, ATC and aircraft.
This assets is generally provided and operated by a service provider

Advanced-Required Navigation Perofrmance. A-RNP applications are supported by GNSS infrastructure. The DME-DME (TACAN for the military) will provide a redundant capability but will not be able to support the highest accuracy requirements of A-RNP

Automatic Dependent Surveillance â Broadcast is a Surveillance technique which relies on aircraft broadcasting their position (calculated by on-board GNSS system), identity and other information derived from on board systems. The ADS-B Ground station receives the 1090 MHz SSR band signals from the Aircraft and converts them to reports in ASTERIX formats for onward transmission. 
The ADS-B Out applications include a) ADS-B in Non Radar Airspace (ADS-B NRA) b) ADS-B in Radar Airspace (ADS-B RAD) c) ADS-B for Aircraft-Derived Data (ADS-B ADD)

ADS â Contract is based on a negotiated one-to-one peer relationship between an Aircraft and an ADS-C Ground station. Using ADS-C, the Aircraft reports can be periodically sent to the controlling ATC centre e.g. during flights over areas without radar coverage.
New aero datalink to provide communications path for passing dynamic situation information (other vehicles, aircraft and runway in use) and required vehicle routeing.
Provide linkage between stakeholders assets networks for the joint availability and use of voice radio stations VoIP for ground segment of Air-Ground voice

Purpose This system contains all the enablers contributing to the production of pure MET information, when fully dedicated to ATM purposes (i.e. generally owned by an ATM stakeholder). Contents It includes sensors (e.g. anemometers, ceilometers, airport MET radars & lidars,..,) and their associated filtering, post-processing, multi-sensor fusion processing systems.

Automatic Dependent Surveillance â Broadcast technique which relies on aircraft/vehicles broadcasting their position (calculated by the GNSS system), identity and other information. The ADS-B Ground station receives the 1090 MHz SSR band signals from the Aircraft/vehicle and converts them to reports in ASTERIX formats for onward transmission The ADS-B Out application for Airport Surface Surveillance  is (ADS-B APT)

Multilateration systems were initially deployed on main airports for the surveillance of aircraft on the surface. The technique is now used to provide surveillance over a larger geographical area.
The Multilateration is an independent Surveillance technique that employs a number of ground stations, placed in TMAs or En-route (or on the airports). The system exploits the 1090 MHz transmissions from aircraft. From these signals it creates a track containing identity, position, height etc., using the time difference of arrival of the signals to the multi-lateration ground stations. The deployment of such systems is already taking place in many areas of Europe exploiting the relatively lower cost compared to a radar, providing surveillance in volumes of airspace not suited to the use of conventional surveillance systems as well as supporting the future evolution towards ADS-B.

This asset aims at grouping all the non-cooperatives sensors that can be used for surface surveillance such as a) Inductive loops detection while an aircraft or vehicle passed over a loop and delivering a positioning information. This enable to track mobiles entering and exiting monitored areas. b) Video camera (trials conducted in Germany and Spain) positions extracted out video feed and converted in ASTERIX data

Airport Surface Movement Radar (SMR) is a primary radar equipment specifically designed to detect aircraft and vehicles on the surface of an airport and to forward this information to the relevant Users in the control tower . 
SMR is used in higher frequency bands (X-Band, Ku-Band).

Represents the ground datalink infrastructure supporting both ACARS and ATN operated and provided by SITA or ARINC .
For example, it represents the SITA ACARS networks equipment's (end-points routers), the DL Host servers in Singapore or Montreal. 
For ATN, it represents the A/G ATN routers and the underlying network infrastructure.

Distance Measuring Equipment (DME) is a ground-based system which transmits a signal to enable aircraft to determine their positions. DME can be paired with VOR or ILS. Several types of DME exist, documented by ICAO in Annex 10; the types studied here are DME/N and DME/P, which uses microwave-band signals. This object covers all DME systems including individual DME beacons.

GBAS station monitors and augments the GNSS signals. It comprises of the Antenna, which receives the GNSS signal; the Correction processor (separate from the GBAS antenna) which receives reference receiver GNSS data, calculates correction data, formats the GBAS message and outputs it to the VDB antenna.
Wake Vortex Detection Radar

ILS systems provide precision approach and landing by broadcasting of the VHF (localizer) and UHF (glide path) signals. ILS systems are providing globally the prime means for precision approach and landing, and will remain initially the prime source for precision approach and landing in the incoming years.
Optical remote sensing technology that can measure the distance to, or other properties of a target by illuminating the target with light, often using pulses from a laser
Light emitting diodes (LEDs) and other lighting infrastructure

MLS has a number of operational and technical advantages over ILS, including much better radio interference immunity, and a much smaller sensitive areas. MLS is still seen as an alternative solution where ILS Cat III level of service can not be achieved or maintained.

Extend linkage of individual aspects of stakeholders local civil/mil provisions,
or
some stakeholders (i.e. CFMU, or national ATC providers) provide the connectivity needed on behalf of their MIL users.

Provide connectivity, bandwidth, and quality of service so support Dynamic Sectorisation and the necessary management of related radio frequencies, VCS systems  and G/G voice links â Digital/VoIP for ground telephony
National networks interconnecting systems within a country (ex. RENAR IP, REDANâ¦)

PSR detects and measures the position (range and bearing) of Aircraft and is used to complement the secondary radar information or to provide positional information on aircraft which are not equipped with SSR avionics or have faulty SSR equipment. The majority of PSR radars for TMA operate in S-Band while the longer range radars operate in L-Band. Mono-static Primary radars are currently the only existing Independent Non-cooperative Surveillance technology. The civil application of Multi-Static Primary Surveillance Radar (MSPSR) is under development. These distributed systems will offer solutions to many of the issues that beset current PSR sensors â (namely extensive spectrum requirements, sensitivity to clutter, high cost etc.)

SSR is used for En-Route and Approach surveillance. It provides the position (range and bearing) of the Aircraft as well as its identity (Mode A code) and altitude (Mode C code)  . The SSR transmits signals on 1030 MHz and receives signals from the transponder on 1090 MHz. 
Mode S SSR (Select) has been replacing the classic Mode A/C interrogation/reply scheme by identifying each Aircraft using a unique 24 bit address. This mode allows downloading additional airborne data from the Aircraft for elementary and enhanced surveillance .

The VHF Omni-directional Radio (VOR) is a navigation aid which transmits a radio frequency carrier. This is associated with two 30 MHz modulations. It can be implemented as Conventional VOR (CVOR) or as Doppler VOR (DVOR). These terms relate to how the modulations are implemented. This object covers all VOR systems including individual VOR stations.

Multilateration systems were initially deployed on main airports for the surveillance of aircraft on the surface. The technique is now used to provide surveillance over a larger geographical area.
The Multilateration is an independent Surveillance technique that employs a number of ground stations, placed in TMAs or En-route (or on the airports). The system exploits the 1090 MHz transmissions from aircraft. From these signals it creates a track containing identity, position, height etc., using the time difference of arrival of the signals to the multi-lateration ground stations. The deployment of such systems is already taking place in many areas of Europe exploiting the relatively lower cost compared to a radar, providing surveillance in volumes of airspace not suited to the use of conventional surveillance systems as well as supporting the future evolution towards ADS-B.

The ACC/Approach Supervisor is responsible for the general management of all activities in the Operations Room. He decides on staffing and manning of controller working positions in accordance with expected traffic demand.

The Airport CDM Project Manager is responsible for ensuring and improving communication between all stakeholders, including data-management of CDM relevant data. This includes the dissemination of airport information like landing time, constraints, turn-round time, Departure Planning Information and received Flight Update Messages, etc.

The APOC supervisor liaises with all APOC participants, acts as a final decision maker in case of issues for which no consensus has been reached.
Changes in responsibilities, Liaison between airport operations and Network, Liaison between airport stakeholders, Ensures that total airport, overview and information is available to all relevant stakeholders, Initiates UDPP when appropriate, Coordinate with the relevant APOC stakeholders on the feasibility of specific airport scenarioâs, Ensures that agreed actions are taken by the appropriate stakeholder(s), Monitors that expected benefits from agreed actions are reached and coordinates any new operational measure if appropriate, Acts as arbitrator in case mutual agreed decision cannot be made in time, Updates the AOP with information within the APOC sphere of responsibility.
Controllers who maintain the safe, orderly and expeditious flow of air traffic in the global air traffic control system
Staff responsible for the engineering of new systems, updates, problems management
Staff responsible for maintenance tasks of the systems deployed within an AC or Tower

The main responsibility of the Air Defence ATC Executive role is to contribute to the safe realisation of a mission inside or outside an ARES.

It is responsible f Maintaining the assets inside the ARES (when the mission takes place in an ARES) Issuing instructions to pilots for conflict resolution vis-a-vis external traffic and or within the mission assets Issuing instructions to pilots for mission completion/realisation Providing situation awareness  Triggering alert in case of emergency Providing any information related to weather forecast, airfield status, etc

Air Defence Supervisor He is responsible for the general management of all activities related to Air defence missions. He decides on staffing in accordance with planning. Heâs responsible for coordinating the activation / de activation or any changes of an ARES with the other (civil & military) supervisors impacted by the ARES.
Whether at the gate or in the flight operation center

The Strategic and CDM Managerâs prime responsibilities are the overall management of the daily operations of the Airspace User and the initiation of CDM processes with concerned partners to resolve potential and existing problems.

Responsible for planning and monitoring the progress of a flight and is an actor normally associated with commercial airline operations. Depending on the modus operandi of the airline, a Flight Dispatcher may have the authority to delay, divert or cancel a flight at any time. Similarly, a flight might not be able to be released from the stand without the signature of both the Captain of the aircraft and the Flight Dispatcher.

Responsible for monitoring the adherence to the airport slots (see definition) allocated to the Airspace User at the bi-annual Coordination Conference. This includes the prioritisation of outbound and inbound flights in a CDM process.  Additionally, the Slot Manager is responsible for negotiating slot exchanges (swaps) with other Airspace Users, e.g. during UDPP, and negotiating with the Airport Slot Coordinator for ad hoc slots.

responsible for the aircraft turn-round in order to manage the aircraft procedures on the ground safely, securely and efficiently. Depending on the AO organization some of these tasks may be carried out by or delegated to Ground Handling Agents

The Airport Duty Officer is the responsible manager for the daily operations, entitled by the airport operator to be in charge of assuring that the airport is operated in accordance with its national licensing conditions and international regulations

- To prepare the allocation of airport slots to Aircraft Operators wanting to operate from/to a fully coordinated airport on a seasonal basis, in a neutral, non-discriminatory and transparent way
- To facilitate the operations of Aircraft Operators at schedule facilitated airports
- To monitor the use of airport slots and adherence of Aircraft Operators to allocated schedules.

The Tower Supervisor is responsible for the safe and efficient provision of air traffic services by the Tower crew. He decides on staffing and manning of controller working positions in accordance with expected traffic demand. He represents the Tower when coordinating with the Airport Operator on operational issues
Mechanics, fuel, maintenance, catering

The main tasks of these bodies are to assess and establish the FAB airspace structures (e.g. FIRs, classification of airspace) and to design the airspace regardless of national boundaries to fulfil civil and military user requirements.

The Airspace Managerâs primary Assertive is to maximise the utilisation of available airspace by dynamic time-sharing and, at times, by segregating airspace among various categories of users based on short-term needs.

Approved Agencies are units which are authorised by States to deal with Airspace Managers for airspace allocation and utilisation matters.Their responsibilities include the submission of their needs for airspace to the AM and of any update on their request. They are permitted to negotiate for airspace to be allocated by AM within the European AFUA (Flexible Use of Airspace) framework constraints. They are also required to ensure that the airspace usage is in accordance with the agreed airspace use plan.

The Apron Manager is responsible for guidance of aircraft to and from the stands (e.g. providing push-back approval), ensuring the safe and efficient movement of aircraft and vehicles within his/her area of responsibility according to local procedures.

The Flight Schedule Planner schedules the flight programme of the airline for each season during the business development phase. The output of the process in Trajectory Management terms is the Business development Trajectory (BDT). The Flight Schedule Planner takes part in the IATA Airport Slot Conferences and it creates the AO Flight Schedule based on the business strategy and on management Assertive of the airline as well as aircraft and flight crew resources

Complexity Management assures that traffic complexity remains within the limits that the controllers can safely cope with. This process supports an efficient provision of Separation Services. Complexity Management detects zones/volumes of high complexity and takes mitigation measures against Controller overloads. The role of Complexity Management may be performed by the Local Traffic Management actor on one end and the Multi Sector Planning actor on the other  These new roles and responsibilities are completely new in the ATM Layered Planning and their final definition and  allocation to adequate actors  is dependent on the validation activities

He is responsible for the safe and expeditious flow of all flights operating within his area of responsibility. His principal tasks are to separate and sequence known flights operating within his area of responsibility and to issue instructions to pilots for conflict resolution and segregated airspace circumnavigation. Additionally, he monitors the trajectory (4D and 3D) of aircraft according to the clearance they have received

His principal task is to check the planned trajectory of aircraft intending to enter his control sector for potential separation risk, and to co-ordinate entry/exit conditions leading to conflict-free trajectories. The role of the PC will remain in sectors other than MSP areas

To ensure that the departing aircraft is free of snow and ice and that the holdover effect of the de-icing treatment is still in effect at the end of taxiing and when take-off clearance of the treated aircraft is given.

The Flight Crew remains ultimately responsible for the safe and orderly operation of the flight in compliance with the ICAO Rules of the Air, other relevant ICAO and CAA/EASA provisions, and within airline standard operating procedures. It ensures that the aircraft operates in accordance with ATC clearances and with the agreed Reference Business Trajectory. For military, some additional rules not covered by ICAO may be implemented by the States for State Aircraft

The Flight Data Operator (FDO) is responsible for validating the flight plan information received from Aircraft Operators (including individual pilots). In addition, the Flight Data Operator provides an advisory service (a help desk) to the individual pilot on flight plan issues when the automated system is unable to provide the assistance required if requested

The main tasks are the update of Flight Dispatch and Business Trajectory Management Systems and Data Bases with aeronautical information as well as company routes and performances. Also the update of other operational documentation such as the AO Operations Manuals is carried out.

The Flow Manager is the point of contact within a FAB for coordination on DCB matters and acts as the interface to the Network Manager and to the local ACC Supervisor and ensures that the ACC is up to date with the demand and capacity situation.

It has the role to execute the aircraft turn-round agreements established with the Aircraft Operators and is responsible for the turn-round of all arriving aircraft. Ground Handling covers a complex series of processes that are required to separate an aircraft from its load (passengers, baggage, cargo and mail) on arrival and combine it with its load prior to departure.

The main tasks of the Local Capacity Manager are performed in the Business Development and in the Medium/Short-term Planning Phase and are to participate in strategic DCB planning meetings, to analyse and establish traffic flows and local capacity values for various sector configurations and airport capabilities and to establish local DCB procedures and practices.

He acts as the coordinating link between the ANSP and regional flow management. The LTM is concerned with the developing forecast of traffic patterns, taking a âhelicopterâ view of complexity and key constraints to traffic flow in the area. He looks at traffic flows covering the period of the Network Operations Plan using all available data.

The Flight programme for military is generally performed by the different forces and command staffs according the national organisation (Air Force, Navy, Army aviation). National and international exercises are part of flight schedules and coordinated in advance at relevant levels between military and civil ATM authorities

The Multi-Sector Planner (MSP) is responsible for a multi-sector area (MSA) comprising of two or more of the present control sectors. The MSP may substitute for the Planning Controller (PC) in some ANSPs and performs planning tasks with an extended planning horizon of up to 20 minutes assisted by automated tools providing conflict resolution and advisories.
Personnel to maintain law, order and safety
RPA remote pilot is the person actively involved in commanding the flight of the RPA by means of C2 (and nose video, depending on type of RPA)
Staff reporting to the Security Manager expert on a given security area (not ICT or systems)
Staff reporting to the Security Manager expert on ICT security
Manager responsible for Security within a given organisation (in principle applicable to ALL organisations)
Staff reporting to the Security Manager expert on systems security

The Stand Planner has the role to of assigning flights/aircraft to their stands on a given airport, taking into account inter alia  aircraft type, aircraft load (e.g. passenger vs. cargo), gate assignment to airlines, origin/destination of flight (e.g. Schengen, international, â¦)

Responsible for providing an Air Traffic Service at controlled aerodromes. His main task is the verification of Flight data (e.g.FPL, CTOT, Stand, TSAT etc) and the delivery of ATC Clearance (Departure Clearance) and Start-Up Approval.

The Tower Ground Controller is part of the controller team responsible for providing an Air Traffic Service at controlled aerodromes. His main task is the provision of ATS to aircraft and vehicles on the manoeuvring area. He must also ensure that airport maintenance vehicles carrying out necessary improvements on an active manoeuvring area do not interfere with the movement of aircraft.

The Tower Runway Controller is responsible for the provision of air traffic services to aircraft within the control zone, or otherwise operating in the vicinity of controlled aerodromes (unless transferred to Approach Control/ACC, or to the Tower Ground Controller), by issuing clearances, instructions and permission to aircraft, vehicles and persons as required for the safe and efficient flow of traffic.
The single main responsibility of the Vehicle Driver is to ensure the safe and efficient movement of his assigned vehicle on the airport manoeuvring area
Personnel of military airspace users on the ground

Part of an aerodrome to be used for the take-off, landing and taxiing of aircraft, consisting of the manoeuvring area and the apron(s).
Airport Infrastructure located outside the terminal infrastructure (Approns, taxi ways, etc)
Description not available
Airport Infrastructure located within the terminal infrastructure (Gates, Terminal, Passenger Services, etc)
This relates to an Air Traffic Control Tower at an Airport/Airfield

Command and control link (C2). The data link between the remotely-piloted aircraft and the remote pilot station for the purposes of command and control the flight.
Nose video data link between the remotely-piloted aircraft and the remote pilot station for the purposes of managing the flight.
Interruption of power supply within a supportive asset or damage to environmental system inside ground station shelter
Physically controlling access in the  RPAS Ground Station Building only to authorised personnel.
Person who repairs or guarantees the complete RPAS to work properly and  payload operator

Ground equipment
Description missing
Description missing
Monitoring of the ATC system to ensure proper work
This functional block provides the functions performed by a Radio VCS

The Information Acquisition & Maintenance function has the role to ensure that all the aeronautical information needed by end users at the local level is available locally (maybe downloaded from another repository) and is kept up-to-date.
Description missing

which ensure that the tools used in the data production chain, as well as in the AIS Provision chain are working properly in accordance with user requirements and service level agreement specifications.

which maintains the list of users (in case of systematic distribution, for example), and also continuously verifies that the users have the appropriate rights to access the requested information (e.g. subscription to the EAD).

This functional bloc provides automatic dynamic ground signs switching and on-board guidance to aircraft, in addition to the current provision of guidance service to aircraft and other vehicles on the apron and the manoeuvring area using visual aids and including lighting systems.

This functional block is responsible for the air-ground communication. Its main role is to handle datalink messages, supporting the exchange of the messages between the TWR and the vehicles and/or the aircrafts on ground

This system allows ATC controllers to interface with the Com system to exchange voice information with Aircraft. This system also manages communication with other ground CC but this not its specificity.
This functional block provides controllers with a graphical user interface and with the means to interact with the Aerodrome ATC system
This function calculates the departure sequence of the flights improving departure flows at airports, taking multiple constraints and preferences into account.

This functional block manages the creation, update and modification of system flight plans up to/from the moment the aircraft takes-off/lands. In addition, it calculates the predicted trajectory by taking into account applicable constraints and relevant data (e.g. aircraft performance, weather data, airport configuration data, wake vortex characteristics associated to each aircraft). Aerodrome Flight Plan should be updated at the occurrence of identified significant events such as, for example request and approval clearance for Start-Up, Push Back, Taxi, Line-Up, Take-Off and similarly for landing aircraft.

The Ground Datalink Management provides the front-end processing to exchange flight data with the CFMU aircraft operators, other civil ATS Units. It also includes the management of the exchanges between Arrival Management and Aerodrome system Departure Management functions.

This function provides the functionalities, for the Aerodrome ATC users, to control and monitoring in real time that the entire light system is constantly able to support the operative needs, in order to assure all the airport operations in an appropriate way under all conditions (e.g. CAT I, CAT II, CAT III). This system is also the main enabler to support and implement the Surface Guidance.

Operational supervision management allows the Tower Supervisor to manage the most appropriate operational configuration, according to traffic demand and aerodrome needs, and react in case of system fault, re-assigning and distributing available resources in order to maintain adequate safety levels and quality of service

This function detects within manoeuvring areas (runway/s and taxiways) potential conflicts between two objects (i.e. aircraft or vehicles), or between an object and a restricted area, by processing the actual traffic situation, It is also extended on final approach and take-off path. The potential safety hazards situations on the airport movement area runway incursion, intrusion in protected areas, aircraft/aircraft and aircraft/vehicle collisions.

The Support functions do not affect directly the provision of ATM services at operational time a) Recording is responsible for performing the recording of the ATM System data related to the Aerodrome ATC, and buffering those data on a persistent database. b) Playback providing support for display and voice recording, display and voice playback, other data recording and reduction, etc. c) Data analysis providing support for maintenance, investigation etc. d) Automatic Safety Data Gathering Tool support for safety aspects.

This functional block aims to select the most appropriate taxi plan for each departing/arriving flight on the basis of the aerodrome flight information, current operational airport resources conditions (i.e. availability and restrictions for surface traffic on runways, taxiways and aircraft stands) and potential interactions with other mobiles.

This function provides controllers with airport situational awareness on landing / take-off paths, apron(s), taxiway(s), runway(s) by providing position and identification, using the Ground Correlation Manager function, of all surface traffic (aircraft and vehicles). It merges the surveillance information provided by the different surveillance sources providing a unique picture of the actual traffic situation. System track is generated for each aircraft, and whenever possible for vehicle and detected obstacle.

This functional block is in charge of the technical supervision of an Aerodrome ATC system (e.g. monitoring the services provided by the system, starting, stopping or re-starting the system or part of it). The Technical Supervision encompasses the following functions
a. Presenting technical and functional systems status monitor system availability.
b. Acquire, synthesize and display technical and functional status on all the system hardware/software resources.
c. Providing failure detection and analysis assistance generate alarm or warning on failure detection. 
d. Provide support for analysis of supervision data (enable queries on historic of events).
e. Providing supervision commands and actions accept supervision commands/actions (e.g. (Re)start/stop/stand-by/reset/switch-over) from eligible operators and gives the capability to perform maintenance activities.
Observation and prediction of low altitude adverse weather conditions
Observation and prediction of the lower atmosphere
TAF, METAR, Aerodrome forecast

By checking continuously the actual aircraft position, this function is responsible for detecting the deviations of each aircraft from its taxi plan (including taxi route, parking-bay, runway, and clearance requested and approved) and/or from planning times. In case of detected deviation this function triggers warnings in order to alert concerned controllers.
This function block provides the functions performed by a Telephone VCS.
It encompasses terrain awareness and avoidance resolutions to avoid terrain encounters.
It encompasses weather information and hazards detection and management which is an autonomous aircraft function for short term awareness related to weather information

This represents the widely recognised term used in standards and requirements for the aircraft function. It represents the data link services, for ATC to Aircraft transactions (e.g. Clearances, Traffic and Flight / Airport / Weather information ), for FOC to Aircraft transactions, and mobile data exchange applications and data protocol mechanisms. In tâe AsâIs situation, most military aircraft do not support Aircraft to ATC transactions (except recent transport-type aircraft). The tactical data links (mostly Link 16) that equip a growing number of military aircraft allow the aircraft to interface with Air Defence centres or WOCs. These tactical data links may be used in the future as a means to interface the military aircraft with ATC
Detects Wake Vortex on board

This represents the basic support for Aircraft to Aircraft, or Aircraft to Ground non-solicited aircraft data broadcasted â this is the ADS-B function.  The current baseline is supported by the transponder (XPDR) 1090 ES (extended squitter). The name was changed from the Definition Phase to better reflect its non-solicited broadcast nature
This corresponds to the control of the aircraft along its trajectory and it encompasses several modes from highly automated to lowly automated.

This functional block encompasses both the in-flight and the surface portions of the trajectory. 
Management of the in-flight portion of the trajectory establishes the trajectory on the basis of defined points and structures in a navigation database established from formally published aeronautical information. It can be Lateral (2D), Vertical (3D), and Time (4D) and it provides the main guidance control orders to maintain the trajectory (the 2 latter involve speed guidance as well), depending on the aircraft functionality implemented. Other Flight Management functions are aircraft performance, predictions, and optimisations.
In a military aircraft, the Flight Management Function, when existing, can be implemented either in an FMS (Flight Management System) or be part of an MMS (Mission Management System), which performs also military-specific functions (e.g. threat assessment, weapon delivery, etc.).
The surface portion of the trajectory is currently controlled by pilots on the basis of digital airport maps airborne traffic surface situation awareness

This represents the aircraft system elaboration of its evolving 4 dimensional position. It is a key low level function to both of the above functions and to ATM. It requires external or aircraft local infrastructures and information for the positioning signals (GNSS, Radio navigation, autonomous aircraft Inertial). Military aircraft may use specific positioning signals (e.g. encrypted GNSS or dedicated NAVAIDS) to achieve the positioning function

This functional block encompasses terrain awareness and avoidance resolutions to avoid terrain encounters. It is a safety net in case of an incorrect flight manoeuvre or deviation when in proximity with terrain (mostly in certain approach conditions). It should be noted that ATM navigation services and trajectories are designed associated with a navigation performance and protected from terrain through structured routes and altitude minima

This encompasses 3 different aspects of traffic surveillance. a) Firstly ATC surveillance, where though a surveillance infrastructure ATC independently establishes the aircraft situation with transponder signals  and/or with aircraft derived information. b) Secondly, airborne traffic situation awareness ATSAW ,which relies on the reception of aircraft-aircraft broadcast data (ADS-B out and in). In tâe AsâIs situation, military aircraft are not equipped with ATSAW. The equivalent military systems based on tactical data links or on-board sensors are not certified for ATM usage c) Thirdly, airborne collision avoidance ACAS, which provides advisories and resolution manoeuvres as last resort safety net (in the case of a traffic separation failure e.g. undetected or incorrect flight manoeuvre or deviation).
Voice mobile communications (which is of 2 basic types  short-range/continental, long-range/remote-oceanic).
Weather information and hazards detection which is an autonomous aircraft function for short term awareness related to hazardous weather / hazardous atmospheric conditions detection.
Integrate Airport operations into the network and improve the overall efficiency of operations at European airports
Manages constraints caused by environmental approvals and regulations at airports directly relating to operations such as noise abatement procedures, night curfews, limited access to runways, etc.

This function provides ground-ground communication directly related to Airport Airside Operations functions and includes communication with
a. Aerodrome ATC
b. AOC/WOC ATM
c. Network Information Management
d. Airspace Management
e. Aeronautical Information Management

This function provides full GL monitoring functionalities for the maintenance users. Ground Lighting Maintenance is a key system for fast monitoring of individual lights providing for example the failed-lamp location details and to control the single lamp.
Vehicles necessary for airport operations (maintenance vehicles, fuel trucks, aircraft rescue and fire fighting vehicles, air traffic control, …)

Function in charge of assessing the airport's performance and improving it. Its main function is to extract, either in real-time or from historic data, commonly agreed key performance indicators (such as take-off punctuality, IATA-punctuality, reliability â¦) from the airport's operational data and to monitor the whole airportâs productive process. It also predicts possible productivity or quality hazards and tracks the incidents that appear. This function provides performance KPIs and performance Alerts.

Monitors current airport demand and capacity and predicts future demand and capacity with regard to operational information and the current weather situation and other disruptions. Unlike Airport Resources and Facilities Management, which operates in real-time, this function mainly uses scheduled flight information; giving a short and mid-term planning to the operators. 
The different Resources to be managed by this function include, but are not limited to (depending on the type, size, operation and location) stands (local and remote), gates, aerobridges, internal buses, ground power units, fuel trucks, de-icing facilities. This function provides Resource and facility assignments / allocation, Resource and facility capacity, Resource and facility capacity alerts.

Wise allocation, assignment and monitoring of airport resources involved in airside operations acting in real-time including demand and capacity. These resources can be either fixed or mobile and are assigned to each operation according to pre-defined rules and constraints (such as each resource can only be used by one aircraft at any one time) and optimizing the airport capacity (e.g. minimizing non-operating displacements). 
The different resources and infrastructure items to be managed by this function include stands (local and remote), gates, aerobridges, internal buses, ground power units, fuel trucks, de-icing facilities.
Runway and Taxi-way usage are out of scope. They are managed by the Aerodrome ATC Domain System. This function provides Resource and facility assignments / allocation, Resource and facility status information, Resource and facility capacity / availability, Resource and facility capacity alerts, Resource and facility conflict alerts.
Function in charge of managing the distribution of airport slots.

These functions involve all factors which are not directly related to Airport Airside Operations services, but to the main functions described previously. They provide processing support for observation (monitoring and control) of system and sub-system (e.g. network infrastructure) performance, and provide tools for maintenance, fault detection, and repair of faulty sub-systems such as
- Meteorology Conditions,
- Technical Supervision,
- Human Machine Interfaces,
- Airport Mapping and Geographical Information System,
- Ground/Ground IOP/SWIM Management,
Facility at an airport from which the airport air traffic is controlled

This FB is in charge of 
a. Monitoring and displaying technical and functional systems status monitor system availability.
Acquire, synthesize and display technical and functional status on all the system hardware/software resources.
b. Providing failure detection and analysis assistance generate alarm or warning on failure detection. Provide support for analysis supervision data (enable queries on historic of events).
c. Providing supervision commands and actions accept supervision commands/actions (e.g. (Re)start/stop/stand-by/reset/switch-over) from eligible operators and gives the capability to perform maintenance activities.
d. Re-configuration of systems to maintain agreed levels of service provision as appropriate; displays supervision information and exports data to external clients (through a dedicated HMI).

Supports turn-round operations (from In-Block to Off-Block). Estimates and predicts accurate throughput times and entry & leaving times, coordinated with Arrival, Departure, Surface and Airport Resources and Facilities Management. Turn-round Management only contributes to time estimation for the RBT concept, but not to Resource Allocation and Planning. This function has a strong inter-dependency with the Departure Management and Surface Guidance Management functions from the Aerodrome ATC system.
Facility responsible for controlling aircraft in approach

EUROCONTROL Network Operations centre,  stem from the Central Flow Management Unit (CFMU). The NOP Portal is a Collaboration application enabling operational stakeholders to interact and collaborate with the Network Manager Operations Centre (formerly CFMU Operations). The NOP (Network Operations Plan) enables a common view of the European ATM network situation to be shared with the whole aviation community. EUROCONTROL's implementation of the NOP through the NOP Portal addresses the need for a single entry point to ATM operations, bringing together various EUROCONTROL tools and information services.
Communisation Gateway for Military-Civil interoperability including SWIM and Datalink.
Aircraft label on radar screen.
children.creator: FM

children.description: The Air-Ground Datalink Management provides the front-end processing to exchange communications and surveillance through standardised communication protocols relayed by external air-ground data communication networks (i.e. the ATN and/or the ACARS networks). This function translates between the generic data-link communications internal protocol (i.e. CM, CPDLC, ADS-C and DFIS) and the two main standard communication protocols (i.e. the ATN/OSI protocol and the ACARS based protocols).

This functional block is responsible for determining an optimal arrival sequence at designated aerodromes and providing associated advisories such as time to lose/gain and Required Time of Arrival. The sequence and advisories are distributed to the Controller Working Positions and to external clients. It includes facilities for manual edition of the sequence

This functional block performs the assignment of SSR Mode 3/A codes to any flight in the controlled airspace according to the allocation plan and the life cycle of the SSR codes (ICAO Originating Region Code Assignment Methâd - ORCAM).

This function is responsible for the detection of Medium-Term and Tactical conflicts between flights and between flights and restricted airspace by analyzing flight trajectories. The function also provides conflict resolution assistance by providing contextual views or resolution context and by providing on-demand resolution advisories.
The Main data used or managed by the function are
- Flight data (SFPL)
- Restricted Airspace
- Aircraft-Aircraft Medium-Term Problems and Conflicts
- Conflict Resolution Advisories
- Aircraft-Airspace Medium-Term Conflicts
The Controller Human Machine Interaction Management encompasses all the functions related to data presentation to controller

This functional block correlates system tracks with flight data (SFPL) based on a mode 3/A code, Aircraft Identification (Mode S or ADS), 24 bit address (when available) and proximity criteria between the system track and the flight trajectory

The Ground-Ground Datalink Management provides the front-end processing to exchange flight data with the CFMU (IFPS and ETFMS), aircraft operators, other civil and military ATS Units, and Air Defence units. The function translates between generic internal protocols and the standard protocols in use with the external systems (e.g. ICAO, ADEXP, OLDI, etc.).

Create a new Functional Bloc supporting ATCOs in identification and resolution of complex situations assessment of evolving traffic patterns and evaluation of opportunities to de-conflict or to synchronise traffic flows (aiming to provide solutions to minimise efficiency in local high complexity/volumes areas)

The Monitoring Aids encompass the following functions
- Flight deviation and conformance monitoring detects if a controlled aircraft deviates from its planned trajectory or from its related clearance, notifying deviation warnings to the concerned sectors.
- Flight progress monitoring and update this function keeps the trajectory updated along the progress of the flight. It also detects certain events such as take-off, missed approach and landing. 
- Reminder tools  reminder of instructions to be issued

Operational supervision management allows the Supervisor to manage the operational configuration, according to traffic demand, and react in case of system fault, re-assigning and distributing available resources in order to maintain adequate safety levels and quality of service.
The Operational Supervision encompasses the following functions
- Managing Sector mapping to Controller Working Position manage immediate or in-advance mapping. Display mapping (operational configuration)
- Managing airspace maps  display airspace maps (static maps, dynamic maps, sector maps). Provide airspace map management tools.
- Managing SFPL data distribution rules enable to modify on-line SFPL data distribution rules.
- Providing dynamic environment data modification assistance enable an operational supervisor to modify manually the environment data (aerodrome group configuration, runway rate, airspace data (holding area, general approval volume), frequency plan, CDR and TSA status, SSR code allotment plan, Holding area).
- Displaying warnings display warnings to the operational supervisor.

This functional block alerts the ATC controllers in case of short-term danger for an aircraft to infringe separation criteria with other aircraft or danger areas.
The safety nets function encompasses the following sub-functions
- Short Term Conflict Alert (STCA) detecting and alerting in case of infringement of separation minima between aircraft.
- Minimum Safe  Altitude Warning (MSAW) detecting and alerting in case of infringement the minimum safe altitude form the ground or from an obstacle.
- Area Proximity Warning (APW) detecting and alerting in case an aircraft is going to infringe a restricted area.
- Approach Path Monitoring (APM) detecting and alerting in case an aircraft deviates from the glide path.

The Support functions do not affect directly the provision of ATM Services at operational time. They encompass the following functions a) Recording to select the data to be recorded and to record these data. b) Data Analysis Function provide a data analysis facility on on-line and for recorded data. c) Data Playback Function  enable to play-back situations from recorded data. d) Configuration Management  providing system version deployment support, the means to assist software and data deployment. e) Managing off-line Environment data provide tools to create, modify, check consistency, compile from different sources, distribute onto sub-systems all the off-line data (airspace definition, air traffic data,â¦) that are required for the systems. Enable Off-line data to be managed both at a national level and at a local level. f) Managing on-line Environment data enable On-line management such as data capture from external clients (Note manual modification of on-line data is addressed in operational supervision function) g) Exchanging environment data with external client distribute Environment data to external clients.

This functional block merges traffic data provided by surveillance sources (PSR, SSR, ADS, WAM) to provide a unique, system-wide reference of the actual air traffic situation. The resultant system tracks are supplemented with flight data and are distributed to other functional blocks for use in controller tools and for display at the CWP, and also to external systems (Airports, Air defence, etc.). 
The surveillance function provides the front-end interfaces as regards surveillance data.
The surveillance function may also receive weather data from PSR sources, which it distributes for display at the CWP.

This functional block is in charge of the technical supervision of an ER/APP ATC system (e.g. monitoring the services provided by the system, starting, stopping or re-starting the system or part of it).
The Technical Supervision encompasses the following functions
- Presenting technical and functional systems status monitor system availability.
Acquire, synthesize and display technical and functional status on all the system hardware/software resources.
- Providing failure detection and analysis assistance generate alarm or warning on failure detection. Provide support for analysis supervision data (enable queries on historic of events).
- Providing supervision commands and actions accept supervision commands/actions (e.g. (Re)start/stop/stand-by/reset/switch-over) from eligible operators and gives the capability to perform maintenance activities.
This function block provides the functions performed by a Telephone VCS.
This functional block provides the functions performed by a Radio VCS
Facility responsible for controlling aircraft en route
corresponds to the management of direct data exchange between the Airspace User and the aircraft (e.g. the uplink of Wind/Temp data via AOC/ACARS for the Step 1 transition phase).

a) the Planning and management of ARES (Area Reservations / Restrictions) including variable profile areas. This function is performed in coordination with ACC and AMC  b) the Sharing of ASM data within sub regional (FABs) and network level (CFMU) using PEN and NOP. This includes the sharing of real time or near-real time airspace status

corresponds to the Business or Mission Trajectory planning, agreement, monitoring and re-planning by the Airspace User (Flight Schedule Staff Member) in collaboration with other ATM Stakeholders, i.e.
corresponds to the management of the whole fleet situation and of the aeronautical information (e.g. AIP, NOTAM)

corresponds to the Business / Mission Development Trajectory scheduling (BDT / MDT), i.e. the long term planning of trajectories by each Airspace User (Flight Schedule Staff Member). It takes into account Airline and Military forecasts, plans, schedules and Airspace/Route design
corresponds to the planning (by the Flight Schedule Staff Member) and management (by the AOC Staff Member) of turn around activities for the whole fleet, i.e. the refuelling, catering, de-icing, etc
corresponds to the management of the reported and forecasted weather information (e.g. TEMSI, Wind/Temp map, SIGMET, TAF/METAR, etc.).
Airborne FMS.
children.creator: FM

children.description: Planning and schedule of flight plans

This FB groups all functions related to Airspace Design. These functions support the development and co-ordination of design activities (at local and regional levels) of the ATS Route Network and ATC Sectors, in both en-route and terminal airspace. This occurs in the strategic phase (months before operations) with 3 time horizons Annual short-term improvements, Medium-term structural airspace improvement and Long term airspace development.

This FB groups all functions for Airspace management, at local, sub-regional and regional levels. These functions support the development and co-ordination of planning activities (at local and regional levels) related to the use of the Airspace (ATS Route Network and ATC Sector configuration), in both en-route and terminal airspace. In terms of time-horizon, Airspace Management activities start after the Airspace Design activities, taking into account the civil and military demand (in terms of airspace reservations and flight plans) as it becomes available the main output is an airspace usage plan, on a daily basis. The functions related to the tactical activation of the elements of this plan (e.g. change of a sector configuration) are not parts of this FB they are parts of the Demand and Capacity Balancing.

This FB groups all functions related to long-term and medium-term capacity planning. These functions support the development and coordination of capacity planning activities at local (ACC) and regional levels. The Network Manager works closely with States, ANSPs, airports and aircraft operators for the enhancement of network capacity, through capacity planning processes and tools

This FB groups all functions related to Demand and capacity balancing in short-term planning phases. It covers the regional and local levels, a DCB measure or a regulation being decided at local levels and its impact being analysed at Regional level. The Demand and capacity balancing FB groups only the functions in the short term planning phases, the time horizon varies from few hours (generally 2 hours) until 20-30 minutes before a demand & capacity unbalance is detected. Therefore this FB can address the execution phase of a flight, the âdemand & capacity balancingâ FB covering the functions to take into account changes happening either in current trajectories update, either in capacity change due to sector configuration modification, meteorological hazards and airspace management decisions
This FB groups all function related to flight assessment and alert, it represent an executive powers in checking the validity of flight plans against the EU blacklist (SAFA).
Network performance monitoring and reporting would analyse the network performance and provide the required reports to network managers and network oversight bodies.

This FB groups all the technical support need at regional or local level. It provides generic system functions that all others FB use. The support includes the relation with the SWIM infrastructure, the connexion to the G/G or A/G IOP and the generic component to manage the NOP (NOP portal, B2B connection mechanism, Supervision).
Meteo service provider
Description missing
Network manager/airspace manager (local)
Network manager/airspace manager (national, functional area block)
Ensure the flow of information necessary for safety, regularity and efficiency of air navigation at national level (ex-AIS)

which receives from the authoritative sources their aeronautical information and ensures that the required up-to-date information is available, either in the local database or directly from the authoritative source to be able to respond to the user needs. This is the function which notably ensures the completeness of the aeronautical information data base.
covers a set of tools and applications which ensures that the data produced meets the relevant data quality standards (includes the implementation of ADQ-1)

which processes the data to deliver the required  break dâ (e.g. result of database query) with the most up-to-date information. This function is responsible for updating the â break doâ according either to required production cycle timeframe (e.g. AIRAC cycle), the issuance of updates the aeronautical data, or to evolution in the production tools (e.g. maintenance of standard queries in relation with database content evolution) or to the specifications agreed with the customer

(e.g. NOTAM) this is a set of tools and applications enabling the entry of data by originators in whichever entity having the right to enter NOTAM, including the verification and validation of these notices by relevant authorities. These tools can be managed at national level or available in the regional system for remote access by users in national AIS organisations;

(e.g. those published in AIP, AIC, SUP, Charts) this is a set of tools and applications spanning from the entry of data provided by data originators, in whichever form (raw data up to already ICAO compliant products) to the eventual assembly of these data into ICAO compliant products. These tools can be managed at national level or available in the regional system for remote access by users in national AIS organisations. The data covered are the aeronautical data (i.e. those specified by Annex 15 and related ICAO SARPS, Guidance Documents and Procedures). They normally include Terrain & Obstacle data (TOD), but depending on the State, this dataset may not be implemented yet.

which ensures that the data meet the quality requirement, but also verifies coherency and consistency of data (e.g. across borders). Quality Management in this functional block includes all the processes and actions necessary to ensure that the âproductâ delivered meets the relevant ADQ2 criteria

which ensure that the tools used in the data production chain, as well as in the AIS Provision chain are working properly in accordance with user requirements and service level agreement specifications.

which maintains the list of users (in case of systematic distribution, for example), and also continuously verifies that the users have the appropriate rights to access the requested information (e.g. subscription to the EAD).
Including Airport, Navigation and Terrain databases, with their update performed periodically.

The initial set of network communication services offered by PENS is expanded, including SWIM and the geographical scope is enlarged to other ANSPs and non-ANSP users like Military authorities, Airlines, Airports, Meteo providers, Industry.
Aircraft system elaboration of its evolving 4 dimensional position.
Description missing
Ensure the flow of information necessary for safety, regularity and efficiency of air navigation at regional level (ex-AIS)
covers a set of tools and applications which ensures that the data produced meets the relevant data quality standards (includes the implementation of ADQ-1)

which ensures that the data meet the quality requirement, but also verifies coherency and consistency of data (e.g. across borders). Quality Management in this functional block includes all the processes and actions necessary to ensure that the âproductâ delivered meets the relevant ADQ2 criteria

which receives from the authoritative sources their aeronautical information and ensures that the required up-to-date information is available, either in the local database or directly from the authoritative source to be able to respond to the user needs. This is the function which notably ensures the completeness of the aeronautical information data base.
This function is responsible to issue updates of the aeronautical data in accordance with the AIRAC cycle.

(e.g. NOTAM) this is a set of tools and applications enabling the entry of data by originators in whichever entity having the right to enter NOTAM, including the verification and validation of these notices by relevant authorities. These tools can be managed at national level or available in the regional system for remote access by users in national AIS organisations;

(e.g. those published in AIP, AIC, SUP, Charts) this is a set of tools and applications spanning from the entry of data provided by data originators, in whichever form (raw data up to already ICAO compliant products) to the eventual assembly of these data into ICAO compliant products. These tools can be managed at national level or available in the regional system for remote access by users in national AIS organisations. The data covered are the aeronautical data (i.e. those specified by Annex 15 and related ICAO SARPS, Guidance Documents and Procedures). They normally include Terrain & Obstacle data (TOD), but depending on the State, this dataset may not be implemented yet.

which ensure that the tools used in the data production chain, as well as in the AIS Provision chain are working properly in accordance with user requirements and service level agreement specifications.

which maintains the list of users (in case of systematic distribution, for example), and also continuously verifies that the users have the appropriate rights to access the requested information (e.g. subscription to the EAD).
Global / Regional (WAFC) products
OPMET centre
Tropical Cyclones Advisories
Volcanic Ash Advisories

This FB groups all functions related to Airspace Design. These functions support the development and co-ordination of design activities (at local and regional levels) of the ATS Route Network and ATC Sectors, in both en-route and terminal airspace. This occurs in the strategic phase (months before operations) with 3 time horizons Annual short-term improvements, Medium-term structural airspace improvement and Long term airspace development.

This FB groups all functions for Airspace management, at local, sub-regional and regional levels. These functions support the development and co-ordination of planning activities (at local and regional levels) related to the use of the Airspace (ATS Route Network and ATC Sector configuration), in both en-route and terminal airspace. In terms of time-horizon, Airspace Management activities start after the Airspace Design activities, taking into account the civil and military demand (in terms of airspace reservations and flight plans) as it becomes available the main output is an airspace usage plan, on a daily basis. The functions related to the tactical activation of the elements of this plan (e.g. change of a sector configuration) are not parts of this FB they are parts of the FB âDemand and Capacity Balancingâ.

This FB groups all functions related to long-term and medium-term capacity planning. These functions support the development and coordination of capacity planning activities at local (ACC) and regional levels. The Network Manager works closely with States, ANSPs, airports and aircraft operators for the enhancement of network capacity, through capacity planning processes and tools

This FB groups all functions related to planning and managing scenarios. These functions cover the regional and local levels, a scenario being elaborated at local level and its impacts being analysed at regional level. The preparation of scenarios is based on CDM processes between the local impacted areas and the regional level. A scenario is elaborated in planning phases and can be activated at the tactical phase when the conditions for its activation occur. The Cooperative Scenario Planning FB groups only the functions in planning phases to prepare the scenarios and to manage them. The tactical activation and the late adaptation of already prepared scenarios in tactical phase is not part of this FB but part of the FB Demand & Capacity Balancing.

This FB groups all functions related to Demand and capacity balancing in short-term planning phases. It covers the regional and local levels, a DCB measure or a regulation being decided at local levels and its impact being analysed at Regional level. The Demand and capacity balancing FB groups only the functions in the short term planning phases, the time horizon varies from few hours (generally 2 hours) until 20-30 minutes before a demand & capacity unbalance is detected. Therefore this FB can address the execution phase of a flight, the demand & capacity balancing FB covering the functions to take into account changes happening either in current trajectories update, either in capacity change due to sector configuration modification, meteorological hazards and airspace management decisions
This FB groups all function related to flight assessment and alert, it represent an executive powers in checking the validity of flight plans against the EU blacklist (SAFA).

This FB groups all functions related to network operation plan management.
These functions cover a regional aspect of the network information management system. The goal is to maintain the best level of information for other stakeholders for all phases (strategic, pre tactical and tactical).
Network performance monitoring and reporting would analyse the network performance and provide the required reports to network managers and network oversight bodies.
This FB groups all functions related to post flight analysis at regional and local levels.

This FB groups all the technical support need at regional or local level. It provides generic system functions that all others FB use. The support includes the relation with the SWIM infrastructure, the connexion to the G/G or A/G IOP and the generic component to manage the NOP (NOP portal, B2B connection mechanism, Supervision).

This FB groups all functions related traffic demand management at regional and local level.
These functions cover regional or local aspect of the demand management during strategic, pre tactical and tactical phase.
The set of offered services and exchanged information between the air & ground SATCOM end-users.

SBAS provides GNSS correction data based on corrections computed at reference stations and uploaded to the system via the control segment, EGNOS â European Geostationary Navigation Overlay Satellites, currently provides correction data for GPS L1. Space segment â Geostationary satellites, Ground segment â Control and Reference stations.

This FB groups all functions related to Airspace Design. These functions support the development and co-ordination of design activities (at local and regional levels) of the ATS Route Network and ATC Sectors, in both en-route and terminal airspace. This occurs in the strategic phase (months before operations) with 3 time horizons Annual short-term improvements, Medium-term structural airspace improvement and Long term airspace development.

This FB groups all functions for Airspace management, at local, sub-regional and regional levels. These functions support the development and co-ordination of planning activities (at local and regional levels) related to the use of the Airspace (ATS Route Network and ATC Sector configuration), in both en-route and terminal airspace. In terms of time-horizon, Airspace Management activities start after the Airspace Design activities, taking into account the civil and military demand (in terms of airspace reservations and flight plans) as it becomes available the main output is an airspace usage plan, on a daily basis. The functions related to the tactical activation of the elements of this plan (e.g. change of a sector configuration) are not parts of this FB they are parts of the FB âDemand and Capacity Balancingâ.

National SIGWX charts

This FB groups all functions related traffic demand management at regional and local level.

It encompasses 3 different aspects of traffic surveillance 
1.       ATC surveillance.
2.       Airborne Traffic Situation Awareness.
3.       Airborne Collision Avoidance.

Voice mobile communications. Two basic types, short range (continental), long-rate (remote-oceanic). 
This includes “VoIP for Ground Communication” according Eurocae ED137

Military airspace user operation centre
corresponds to the management of direct data exchange between the Airspace User and the aircraft (e.g. the uplink of Wind/Temp data via AOC/ACARS for the Step 1 transition phase).

a) the Planning and management of ARES (Area Reservations / Restrictions) including variable profile areas. This function is performed in coordination with ACC and AMC b) the Sharing of ASM data within sub regional (FABs) and network level (CFMU) using PEN and NOP. This includes the sharing of real time or near-real time airspace status

corresponds to the Business / Mission Development Trajectory scheduling (BDT / MDT), i.e. the long term planning of trajectories by each Airspace User (Flight Schedule Staff Member). It takes into account Airline and Military forecasts, plans, schedules and Airspace/Route design

corresponds to the Business or Mission Trajectory planning, agreement, monitoring and re-planning by the Airspace User (Flight Schedule Staff Member) in collaboration with other ATM Stakeholders, i.e.
corresponds to the management of the whole fleet situation and of the aeronautical information (e.g. AIP, NOTAM)
corresponds to the management of ATM data exchange via the SWIM enabled NOP
corresponds to the planning (by the Flight Schedule Staff Member) and management (by the AOC Staff Member) of turn around activities for the whole fleet, i.e. the refuelling, catering, de-icing, etc
corresponds to the management of the reported and forecasted weather information (e.g. TEMSI, Wind/Temp map, SIGMET, TAF/METAR, etc.).
